        <div class="pageTitle"> 
         <h1 class="syndicate"> Swim Safely: Quick tips </h1> 
         <img id="content_contentImage" class="icon-image" alt="Swim Safely: Quick tips" src="/HealthTopics/glmedia/tools_icons/swimsafelyquicktips.jpg"> 
        </div> 
        <div class="content-page-box clearfix"> 
         <div class="quickguide_tool_content syndicate"> 
          <div class="entry-content-top"> 
           <p>Swimming is a great way for the whole family to get active. Follow these tips to stay safe in and around the water.</p> 
          </div> 
          <div class="entry-content-main"> 
           <h2>Swim safely.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>Swim near a lifeguard and never swim alone.</li>
            <li>Dont drink alcohol if you are swimming or watching children swim.</li>
            <li>Use floating toys like water wings and noodles for fun  not for safety. Dont use them in place of life jackets.</li>
            <li>Watch out for rip currents. A rip current is when the water pulls you away from shore. If you get caught in a rip current, swim along the shoreline until you are out of the current, then swim to shore.</li>
           </ul>
           <h2>Take a class.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>Take swim lessons if you dont know how to float, tread water, and swim.</li>
            <li>Sign your kids up for swim lessons as soon as they are ready  this can be as early as age 1.</li>
            <li>Learn CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation). Your skills could save someone's life.&nbsp;</li>
           </ul>
           <h2>Watch children carefully.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>Drowning happens quickly and quietly.&nbsp;Make sure at least 1 adult is always watching when children are in or around the water, even if they know how to swim.&nbsp;</li>
            <li>Dont read or use the phone while you are watching young children.</li>
           </ul>
           <h2>Make sure pools are safe.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>If you have a pool, install a 4-sided pool fence thats at least 4 feet high to separate&nbsp;the pool from the house and yard.</li>
            <li>Use self-closing and self-latching gates that open outward and are out of reach of children.&nbsp;That way,&nbsp;kids cant get near the water&nbsp;when you arent watching them.</li>
           </ul>
           <h2>Check water and weather conditions before going swimming.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>Get out of the water right away if you hear thunder or see lightning. Strong winds can also be dangerous.</li>
            <li>Learn the meaning of colored safety flags used at the beach&nbsp;and obey all warnings.</li>
            <li>Dont swim in the ocean, lakes, or rivers after heavy rain. Water is more likely to be polluted after a rain storm.</li>
            <li>Check for signs or warnings about bacteria or other pollution in the water before swimming.</li>
           </ul>
           <h2>Protect yourself and others from germs in the water.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>Try not to get water in your mouth.</li>
            <li>Make sure everyone is clean before swimming. Shower with soap. Wash your hands after using the bathroom or changing diapers.</li>
            <li>Take your kids on bathroom breaks or check diapers often. Change diapers in a bathroom or a diaper-changing area.</li>
           </ul>
           <h2>Protect your skin from the sun.</h2>
           <ul>
            <li>Wear plenty of sunscreen with a minimum SPF of 15.</li>
            <li>Put on more sunscreen every 2 hours and after swimming or sweating.</li>
           </ul> 
          </div> 
          <div id="content_resourceLinks"> 
           <div class="resource-links clearfix"> 
            <p class="last-updated"> <strong>Content last updated on:</strong> March 19, 2019 </p>
